newsitem.title: GERMANY: Shipper demands more electronic, Internet systems.
newsitem.headline: Shipper demands more electronic, Internet systems.

text.p: Transport companies must give a higher priority to better electronic communications systems and Internet-based services, a large German shipper said.
Bernd Mueller, transport manager of Bertelsmann Distribution GmbH, a subsidiary of media giant Bertelsmann, said his company faced problems in trying to distribute throughout Europe.
These included long transport times, high costs and complicated paperwork for non-EU destinations, he said in a speech to the third European courier, express and parcels congress in Bonn.
Shippers wanted value-for-money international parcels distribution and simple documentation with paper-free administration within the EU, he said.
"Paper must disappear. Any (distribution) company using paper will no longer be used by us," he said.
Instead, open computer systems with flexible interfaces and Internet-based tracking and tracing of shipments should be offered by transport companies, Mueller said.
"In my view, it is vital in the express and courier areas that this is done," he told company managers.
Bertelsmann wanted to integrate online tracking and tracing into its client complaint network so that distribution problems could be quickly tackled, he added.
Direct distribution to private clients in Europe was also a requirement which only Deutsche Post and other post offices could meet at present, he noted.
But Mueller forecast: "In 2003 we will have open systems on an Internet/Intranet basis, paperless invoicing and computer-based customs declarations."
Integrated standard transport systems would offer Europe-wide distribution, including to private clients, at value-for-money prices, he added.
Bertelsmann Distribution handled 100,000 consignments a day, including 3,000 export consignments, he said.

The company used currently many operators, including DHL Worldwide Express GmbH, UPS, TNT Worldwide Express, Deutsche Post AG, DPD and German Parcel. - Reuters Air Cargo Newsroom. Tel+44 171 542 7706; Fax:5017
